Federated Learning with Communication
Delay in Edge Networks

Frank Po-Chen Lin, Christopher G. Brinton, Nicolò Michelusi School of Electrical and Computer Engineering, Purdue University, USA
Email: {lin1183,cgb,michelus}@purdue.edu
Abstract

Federated learning has received significant attention as a potential solution for distributing machine learning (ML) model training through edge networks. This work addresses an important consideration of federated learning at the network edge: communication delays between the edge nodes and the aggregator. A technique called FedDelAvg (federated delayed averaging) is developed, which generalizes the standard federated averaging algorithm to incorporate a weighting between the current local model and the delayed global model received at each device during the synchronization step. Through theoretical analysis, an upper bound is derived on the global model loss achieved by FedDelAvg, which reveals a strong dependency of learning performance on the values of the weighting and learning rate. Experimental results on a popular ML task indicate significant improvements in terms of convergence speed when optimizing the weighting scheme to account for delays.

Index Terms:
Federated learning, edge intelligence, distributed machine learning, convergence analysis, edge-cloud computing

I Introduction

Rapid developments of communications technology in conjunction with machine learning (ML) algorithms has resulted in an exponential rise in data generated by user devices [1]. A paradigm shift is occurring from the conventional cloud computing architecture to a hybrid cloud-edge model where ML data processing is carried out on edge devices for many applications, particularly latency-sensitive tasks [2].

Federated learning (FL) has emerged as a promising solution for distributing the training of ML models across edge devices. FL techniques, such as the popular FedAvg algorithm [3], generally consist of three steps repeated in sequence: (i) several iterations of parallel, local model training at each device using their own local datasets, (ii) aggregation of the local models at an edge server into a single, global model, and (iii) synchronization of the local models at each device with this global model.

Several research efforts have been conducted on federated learning in recent years to address challenges such as reducing communication overhead and analyzing convergence rates. In this paper, we consider another important aspect of FL that arises in edge networks: communication delays between the edge devices and server performing the aggregations. Our proposed algorithm, FedDelAvg, serves the dual purpose of quantifying the impact of such delays and optimizing model performance in their presence.

I-1 Related work

We divide related work on federated learning into two categories: studies on (i) reducing communication bandwidth requirements and (ii) obtaining model convergence bounds. For a recent, comprehensive survey of works on FL, see [4].

Reducing communication requirements. Edge networks can have unreliable communication environments (e.g., variable wireless connections), which can impact distributed ML techniques. For this reason, [3, 5] proposed methods to reduce the number of upstream and downstream communication rounds required in FL. Other efforts have focused on reducing communication demand per round; in particular, [6, 7, 8] proposed gradient compression methods to reduce the bandwidth required in each transmission. Recently, [9] proposed a network-aware FL architecture which trades off communication demand with model convergence.

Model convergence bounds. Other work on FL has studied model convergence under different data distributions and local update models. [10] showed that the error bound of FL in the case of non-Independent and Identically Distributed (non-i.i.d.) data samples becomes worse than i.i.d., while [11] analyzed the convergence of the FedAvg algorithm, suggesting conditions on the learning rate to achieve the optimum. [12] discovered that training may converge faster with batch gradient descent, assuming that all edge devices participate throughout the training process. Most recently, [13] analyzed the convergence bound of FL in the presence of a total network resource budget constraint.

The above-mentioned works do not consider the effect of network delays. In practice, delays between the edge devices and the cloud are non negligible – usually from hundreds of milliseconds to several seconds depending on the network bandwidth [6] – which might severely degrade the performance of FL schemes. This aspect is the focus of our work.

I-2 Outline of contributions

We propose FedDelAvg, a novel technique that adapts FL in the presence of network delays. Specifically, we develop a new algorithm for the synchronization step that combines local and global models to account for the effects of delay (Section II). Then, we characterize convergence of FedDelAvg and provide suggestions for the optimal weight used in the synchronization phase (Section III). Finally, the delay-robustness of FedDelAvg on convergence speed is demonstrated numerically when the synchronization weighting is adjusted for delay (Section IV).

II FedDelAvg: Federated Delayed Averaging

In this section, we introduce the federated learning system model, the machine learning task model, and develop FedDelAvg, our federated delayed averaging algorithm.

II-A Edge Network Model

The federated learning (FL) system architecture consists of a single edge server and multiple edge devices indexed by i=1,2,…,N𝑖12…𝑁i=1,2,...,N, as shown in Fig.1. The edge devices collect data and perform local updates to optimize a loss function F​(⋅)𝐹⋅F(\cdot) corresponding to a machine learning task (described next). The edge server (the cloud) plays the role of an aggregator, collecting the locally trained parameters 𝐰isubscript𝐰𝑖\mathbf{w}_{i} and the corresponding local loss functions Fi​(𝐰i)subscript𝐹𝑖subscript𝐰𝑖F_{i}(\mathbf{w}_{i}) from the edge devices to perform a global update. Local updates are taken to be gradient descent steps on the local loss functions Fi​(𝐰)subscript𝐹𝑖𝐰F_{i}(\mathbf{w}), while global updates refers to aggregation followed by synchronization. Aggregation denotes the computation of a global model obtained using the weighted average of local models, while synchronization represents the update of local models at the edge after aggregation [9].

In an edge network, the aggregation of the local model parameters at the cloud followed by the synchronization at the edge incurs communication delay, which we aim to model in our formulation.

II-B Machine Learning Model

II-B1 Data structure

Each device i𝑖i carries a dataset 𝒟isubscript𝒟𝑖\mathcal{D}_{i} with Di=|𝒟i|subscript𝐷𝑖subscript𝒟𝑖D_{i}=|\mathcal{D}_{i}| data points. Each data point (𝐱,y)∈𝒟i𝐱𝑦subscript𝒟𝑖(\mathbf{x},y)\in\mathcal{D}_{i} consists of an m𝑚m-dimensional feature vector 𝐱∈ℝm𝐱superscriptℝ𝑚\mathbf{x}\in\mathbb{R}^{m} and a label y∈ℝ𝑦ℝy\in\mathbb{R}.

II-B2 Loss function

We let fi​(𝐱,y;𝐰)subscript𝑓𝑖𝐱𝑦𝐰f_{i}(\mathbf{x},y;\mathbf{w}) be the loss associated with the data point (𝐱,y)∈𝒟i𝐱𝑦subscript𝒟𝑖(\mathbf{x},y)\in\mathcal{D}_{i} based on a model parameter vector 𝐰∈ℝm𝐰superscriptℝ𝑚\mathbf{w}\in\mathbb{R}^{m}. For instance, in linear regression, the loss function is the squared error fi​(𝐱,y;𝐰)=12​(y−𝐰T​𝐱)2subscript𝑓𝑖𝐱𝑦𝐰12superscript𝑦superscript𝐰𝑇𝐱2f_{i}(\mathbf{x},y;\mathbf{w})=\frac{1}{2}(y-\mathbf{w}^{T}\mathbf{x})^{2}. We define the loss function across the local dataset 𝒟isubscript𝒟𝑖\mathcal{D}_{i} as

Fi​(𝐰)=1Di​∑(𝐱,y)∈𝒟ifi​(𝐱,y;𝐰),subscript𝐹𝑖𝐰1subscript𝐷𝑖subscript𝐱𝑦subscript𝒟𝑖subscript𝑓𝑖𝐱𝑦𝐰\displaystyle F_{i}(\mathbf{w})=\frac{1}{D_{i}}\sum\limits_{(\mathbf{x},y)\in\mathcal{D}_{i}}f_{i}(\mathbf{x},y;\mathbf{w}), (1)

and the global loss function across all nodes can then be expressed as

F​(𝐰)=∑i=1Nρi​Fi​(𝐰),𝐹𝐰superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁subscript𝜌𝑖subscript𝐹𝑖𝐰\displaystyle F(\mathbf{w})=\sum\limits_{i=1}^{N}\rho_{i}F_{i}(\mathbf{w}), (2)

where ρi=Di/∑jDjsubscript𝜌𝑖subscript𝐷𝑖subscript𝑗subscript𝐷𝑗\rho_{i}=D_{i}/\sum_{j}D_{j} is the weight associated with the i𝑖ith node, proportional to the size of the local dataset.

II-B3 Learning objective

The goal of the machine learning task is to find the 𝐰∗superscript𝐰\mathbf{w}^{*} that minimizes F​(𝐰)𝐹𝐰F(\mathbf{w}), i.e.,

𝐰∗=arg⁡min𝐰F​(𝐰).superscript𝐰subscript𝐰𝐹𝐰\displaystyle\mathbf{w}^{*}=\mathop{\arg\min_{\mathbf{w}}}F(\mathbf{w}). (3)

To aid our analysis in Section III, we make a few standard assumptions [3] on the local loss functions Fisubscript𝐹𝑖F_{i}.

Assumption 1.

Fisubscript𝐹𝑖F_{i} is continuously differentiable, convex, L𝐿L-Lipschitz and β𝛽\beta-smooth, implying that

|Fi​(𝐰1)−Fi​(𝐰2)|≤L​‖𝐰1−𝐰2‖,subscript𝐹𝑖subscript𝐰1subscript𝐹𝑖subscript𝐰2𝐿normsubscript𝐰1subscript𝐰2\displaystyle|F_{i}(\mathbf{w}_{1})-F_{i}(\mathbf{w}_{2})|\leq L\|\mathbf{w}_{1}-\mathbf{w}_{2}\|, (4)
‖∇Fi​(𝐰1)−∇Fi​(𝐰2)‖≤β​‖𝐰1−𝐰2‖,norm∇subscript𝐹𝑖subscript𝐰1∇subscript𝐹𝑖subscript𝐰2𝛽normsubscript𝐰1subscript𝐰2\displaystyle\|\nabla F_{i}(\mathbf{w}_{1})-\nabla F_{i}(\mathbf{w}_{2})\|\leq\beta\|\mathbf{w}_{1}-\mathbf{w}_{2}\|, (5)

where L∈[0,∞)𝐿0L\in[0,\infty) and β∈[0,∞)𝛽0\beta\in[0,\infty) are the Lipschitz and smoothness constants, respectively.

By (2), Assumption 1 holds for the global loss function F𝐹F too. One example of Fisubscript𝐹𝑖F_{i} that satisfies Assumption 1 is the well-known logistic regression loss.

We now state an important assumption on the dissimilarity of data at the edge devices, in addition to Assumption 1:

Assumption 2.

The gradients of the local and global loss functions exhibit a similarity of

‖∇Fi​(𝐰)−∇F​(𝐰)‖≤δi,∀𝐰,norm∇subscript𝐹𝑖𝐰∇𝐹𝐰subscript𝛿𝑖for-all𝐰\displaystyle\|\nabla F_{i}(\mathbf{w})-\nabla F(\mathbf{w})\|\leq\delta_{i},\ \forall\mathbf{w}, (6)

where 2​L≥δi≥02𝐿subscript𝛿𝑖02L\geq\delta_{i}\geq 0 is the dissimilarity parameter for node i𝑖i.

We let δ=∑iρi​δi𝛿subscript𝑖subscript𝜌𝑖subscript𝛿𝑖\delta=\sum_{i}\rho_{i}\delta_{i} be the average data dissimilarity across the edge network.

II-B4 Centralized gradient descent

Loss functions are typically minimized by gradient descent (GD) iterations. In a centralized case, where the global loss F𝐹F can be optimized directly, this is defined as

𝐰G​D​(t)=𝐰G​D​(t−1)−η​∇F​(𝐰G​D​(t−1)),subscript𝐰𝐺𝐷𝑡subscript𝐰𝐺𝐷𝑡1𝜂∇𝐹subscript𝐰𝐺𝐷𝑡1\displaystyle\mathbf{w}_{GD}(t)=\mathbf{w}_{GD}(t-1)-\eta\nabla F(\mathbf{w}_{GD}(t-1)),\ (7)

where 𝐰G​D​(0)subscript𝐰𝐺𝐷0\mathbf{w}_{GD}(0) is an initialization, t≥1𝑡1t\geq 1 is the iteration index, and η>0𝜂0\eta>0 is the learning rate. If F𝐹F is convex and η≤1β𝜂1𝛽\eta\leq\frac{1}{\beta}, then gradient descent converges to the globally optimal solution 𝐰∗superscript𝐰\mathbf{w}^{*} with rate 𝒪​(1/T)𝒪1𝑇\mathcal{O}(1/T), where T𝑇T is the number of iterations [14].

However, centralized gradient descent cannot be directly applied to the FL framework in Fig.1 since no device has direct access to all the data. In addition, communication to the cloud is costly in terms of network resources, so the aggregation and synchronization processes are done only periodically. Finally, communication delay between edge and cloud is usually non-negligible, which we address next in developing the FedDelAvg algorithm.

II-C FedDelAvg Algorithm

In FedDelAvg, i.e., Federated Delayed Averaging, the effect of communication delay between edge and cloud on learning performance is incorporated into the design of the FL system. We divide the learning process into discrete time intervals t∈{1,2,…,T}𝑡12…𝑇t\in\{1,2,...,T\}, where the duration between two consecutive aggregations is denoted as τ𝜏\tau. The communication delay between the time when edge devices send their updates to the cloud and the resulting synchronization is denoted ΔΔ\Delta, where τ≥Δ≥0𝜏Δ0\tau\geq\Delta\geq 0. In Fig.1, we assume a symmetric delay of τ/2𝜏2\tau/2 upstream and downstream.

II-C1 Distributed gradient descent incorporating delay

We let 𝐰i​(t)subscript𝐰𝑖𝑡\mathbf{w}_{i}(t) be the local model parameter vector of edge device i𝑖i at time t𝑡t, initialized as 𝐰i​(−Δ)=𝐰​(−Δ)subscript𝐰𝑖Δ𝐰Δ\mathbf{w}_{i}(-\Delta)=\mathbf{w}(-\Delta) at time −ΔΔ-\Delta across all devices. Let

𝐰​(t)=∑iρi​𝐰i​(t)𝐰𝑡subscript𝑖subscript𝜌𝑖subscript𝐰𝑖𝑡\displaystyle\mathbf{w}(t)=\sum\limits_{i}\rho_{i}\mathbf{w}_{i}(t) (8)

be the weighted average of the parameter vectors across the edge devices at t𝑡t. 𝐰i​(t)subscript𝐰𝑖𝑡\mathbf{w}_{i}(t) is sent at t∈{k​τ−Δ,∀k≥0}𝑡𝑘𝜏Δfor-all𝑘0t\in\{k\tau-\Delta,\forall k\geq 0\}, 𝐰​(t)𝐰𝑡\mathbf{w}(t) is computed after the network delay (e.g. Δ/2Δ2\Delta/2) at the cloud, for times t∈{k​τ−Δ/2,∀k≥0}𝑡𝑘𝜏Δ2for-all𝑘0t\in\{k\tau-\Delta/2,\forall k\geq 0\} as a result of aggregation, and is then received at the edge devices at time t+Δ𝑡Δt+\Delta. We partition the time interval (−Δ,T−Δ]Δ𝑇Δ(-\Delta,T-\Delta] of duration T𝑇T into K=T/τ𝐾𝑇𝜏K=T/\tau periods, each of duration τ𝜏\tau (without loss of generality, we assume T𝑇T is an integer multiple of τ𝜏\tau).

Consider the k𝑘kth period, k∈{0,…,K−1}𝑘0…𝐾1k\in\{0,\dots,K-1\}, spanning the time interval 𝒯k={k​τ−Δ+1,…,(k+1)​τ−Δ}subscript𝒯𝑘𝑘𝜏Δ1…𝑘1𝜏Δ\mathcal{T}_{k}=\{k\tau-\Delta+1,...,(k+1)\tau-\Delta\}. At each time t∈𝒯k∖{k​τ}𝑡subscript𝒯𝑘𝑘𝜏t\in\mathcal{T}_{k}\setminus\{k\tau\}, each edge device performs local GD updates as

𝐰i​(t)=𝐰i​(t−1)−η​∇Fi​(𝐰i​(t−1)).subscript𝐰𝑖𝑡subscript𝐰𝑖𝑡1𝜂∇subscript𝐹𝑖subscript𝐰𝑖𝑡1\displaystyle\mathbf{w}_{i}(t)=\mathbf{w}_{i}(t-1)-\eta\nabla F_{i}(\mathbf{w}_{i}(t-1)). (9)

At time t=k​τ𝑡𝑘𝜏t=k\tau (synchronization), each edge device receives the delayed global parameter vector 𝐰​(t−Δ)𝐰𝑡Δ\mathbf{w}(t-\Delta) from the cloud. To update the local model, each device first performs a local GD update, followed by a weighted average between the local and global variables; mathematically, at time t=k​τ𝑡𝑘𝜏t=k\tau,

𝐰i​(t)=subscript𝐰𝑖𝑡absent\displaystyle\mathbf{w}_{i}(t)= α​𝐰​(t−Δ)𝛼𝐰𝑡Δ\displaystyle\alpha\mathbf{w}(t-\Delta)
+(1−α)​[𝐰i​(t−1)−η​∇Fi​(𝐰i​(t−1))],1𝛼delimited-[]subscript𝐰𝑖𝑡1𝜂∇subscript𝐹𝑖subscript𝐰𝑖𝑡1\displaystyle+(1-\alpha)\left[\mathbf{w}_{i}(t-1)-\eta\nabla F_{i}(\mathbf{w}_{i}(t-1))\right], (10)

where α∈[0,1]𝛼01\alpha\in[0,1] is a weight parameter weighting the local vs. global updates. Note that, when α=1𝛼1\alpha=1 and Δ=0Δ0\Delta=0, we obtain [3] as a special case. Letting

Since edge devices send their local parameters 𝐰i​(t)subscript𝐰𝑖𝑡\mathbf{w}_{i}(t) and the corresponding local loss functions Fi​(𝐰i​(t))subscript𝐹𝑖subscript𝐰𝑖𝑡F_{i}(\mathbf{w}_{i}(t)) to the cloud at t=k​τ−Δ𝑡𝑘𝜏Δt=k\tau-\Delta, the cloud only has access to the global model 𝐰​(t)𝐰𝑡\mathbf{w}(t) and F​(𝐰​(t))𝐹𝐰𝑡F(\mathbf{w}(t)) at times t=k​τ−Δ𝑡𝑘𝜏Δt=k\tau-\Delta. 𝐰K=arg⁡min𝐰∈𝒲F​(𝐰),superscript𝐰𝐾subscript𝐰𝒲𝐹𝐰\displaystyle\mathbf{w}^{K}=\mathop{\arg\min_{\mathbf{w}\in\mathcal{W}}}F(\mathbf{w}), (13)

III Convergence Analysis of FedDelAvg

In this section, we study the convergence of FedDelAvg in terms of the optimality gap F​(𝐰K)−F​(𝐰∗)𝐹superscript𝐰𝐾𝐹superscript𝐰F(\mathbf{w}^{K})-F(\mathbf{w}^{*}) between the global objective function at the algorithm output 𝐰Ksuperscript𝐰𝐾\mathbf{w}^{K} and at the globally optimal parameter vector 𝐰∗superscript𝐰\mathbf{w}^{*}.

Definition 1.

For each period k∈{0,…,K−1}𝑘0…𝐾1k\in\{0,\dots,K-1\}, as in [13], we define 𝐜k​(t)subscript𝐜𝑘𝑡\bm{c}_{k}(t) as the centralized gradient descent algorithm during the time interval t∈𝒯k𝑡subscript𝒯𝑘t\in\mathcal{T}_{k}, i.e.,

𝒄k​(t)=𝒄k​(t−1)−η​∇F​(𝒄k​(t−1)),subscript𝒄𝑘𝑡subscript𝒄𝑘𝑡1𝜂∇𝐹subscript𝒄𝑘𝑡1\displaystyle\bm{c}_{k}(t)=\bm{c}_{k}(t-1)-\eta\nabla F(\bm{c}_{k}(t-1)), (14)

initialized as 𝐜k​(k​τ−Δ)=𝐰​(k​τ−Δ)subscript𝐜𝑘𝑘𝜏Δ𝐰𝑘𝜏Δ\bm{c}_{k}(k\tau-\Delta)=\mathbf{w}(k\tau-\Delta).

III-A Optimality Gap and Optimization

The main result is demonstrated in Theorem 1, which upper bounds the optimality gap under delay.

Theorem 1.

Under Assumption 1 and with η<2β𝜂2𝛽\eta<\frac{2}{\beta},

We discuss the proof of Theorem 1 in Section III-B. Theorem 1 demonstrates that the performance of FedDelAvg under communication delay is strongly dependent on the learning rate η𝜂\eta and on the value of the weighting α𝛼\alpha used in the synchronization phase, indicating that these algorithm parameters should be carefully selected with respect to the communication delay in a given learning environment. One way to design α𝛼\alpha and η𝜂\eta is to minimize the asymptotic optimality gap, achieved in the limit T→∞→𝑇T\to\infty. In this case, we obtain

limK→∞F​(𝐰K)−F​(𝐰∗)≤Lη​ϕ​τ​ψ​(α,∞)+L​ψ​(α,∞),subscript→𝐾𝐹superscript𝐰𝐾𝐹superscript𝐰𝐿𝜂italic-ϕ𝜏𝜓𝛼𝐿𝜓𝛼\displaystyle\lim_{K\to\infty}F(\mathbf{w}^{K})-F(\mathbf{w}^{*})\leq\sqrt{\frac{L}{\eta\phi\tau}}\sqrt{\psi(\alpha,\infty)}+L\psi(\alpha,\infty), (20)

where

ψ​(α,∞)=(1−α)​2​η​L​(τ/α−Δ)​[(1+η​β)τ−1]𝜓𝛼1𝛼2𝜂𝐿𝜏𝛼Δdelimited-[]superscript1𝜂𝛽𝜏1\displaystyle\psi(\alpha,\infty)=(1-\alpha)2\eta L(\tau/\alpha-\Delta)[(1+\eta\beta)^{\tau}-1] (21)
+(1−α)​h​(τ)+α​h​(τ−Δ)+α​η​Δ​L​(1+η​β)τ−Δ.1𝛼ℎ𝜏𝛼ℎ𝜏Δ𝛼𝜂Δ𝐿superscript1𝜂𝛽𝜏Δ\displaystyle+(1-\alpha)h(\tau)+\alpha h(\tau-\Delta)+\alpha\eta\Delta L(1+\eta\beta)^{\tau-\Delta}.

Note that (20) is increasing in ψ​(α,∞)𝜓𝛼\psi(\alpha,\infty). Therefore, the optimal value of α𝛼\alpha is the minimizer of ψ​(α,∞)𝜓𝛼\psi(\alpha,\infty) in (21). When the delay is negligible (Δ=0Δ0\Delta=0), we obtain

ψ​(α,∞)𝜓𝛼\displaystyle\psi(\alpha,\infty) =h​(τ)+(α−1−1)​2​η​L​τ​[(1+η​β)τ−1]absentℎ𝜏superscript𝛼112𝜂𝐿𝜏delimited-[]superscript1𝜂𝛽𝜏1\displaystyle=h(\tau)+(\alpha^{-1}-1)2\eta L\tau[(1+\eta\beta)^{\tau}-1] (22)
≥ψ​(1,∞),absent𝜓1\displaystyle\geq\psi(1,\infty),

and therefore the asymptotic optimality gap in (20) is minimized by choosing α=1𝛼1\alpha=1. In this case, we obtain the FedAvg algorithm derived in [13, Theorem 2] as a special case of our analysis. Intuitively, α=1𝛼1\alpha=1 is the optimum for this special case because the global model obtained by the cloud at t=k​τ𝑡𝑘𝜏t=k\tau is built based on the weighted average of up-to-date local models.

Our analysis generalizes that in [13, Theorem 2] by incorporating communication delay, and by allowing α∈(0,1]𝛼01\alpha\in(0,1] in the synchronization phase. In this case, the term ψ​(α,∞)𝜓𝛼\psi(\alpha,\infty) is an increasing function of α∈(0,1]𝛼01\alpha\in(0,1] iff

α2{ηΔL[2(1+ηβ)τ+(1+ηβ)τ−Δ−2]\displaystyle\alpha^{2}\Big{\{}\eta\Delta L[2(1+\eta\beta)^{\tau}+(1+\eta\beta)^{\tau-\Delta}-2]
−δβ(1+ηβ)τ−Δ[(1+ηβ)Δ−1]+ηδΔ}\displaystyle-\frac{\delta}{\beta}(1+\eta\beta)^{\tau-\Delta}[(1+\eta\beta)^{\Delta}-1]+\eta\delta\Delta\Big{\}}
≥2​η​L​τ​[(1+η​β)τ−1].absent2𝜂𝐿𝜏delimited-[]superscript1𝜂𝛽𝜏1\displaystyle\geq 2\eta L\tau[(1+\eta\beta)^{\tau}-1].

Note that, if

δ≥η​β​L​Δ​(1+η​β)τ−Δ−2​[(1+η​β)τ−1]​(τ−Δ)(1+η​β)τ−(1+η​β)τ−Δ−η​β​Δ𝛿𝜂𝛽𝐿Δsuperscript1𝜂𝛽𝜏Δ2delimited-[]superscript1𝜂𝛽𝜏1𝜏Δsuperscript1𝜂𝛽𝜏superscript1𝜂𝛽𝜏Δ𝜂𝛽Δ\displaystyle\delta\geq\eta\beta L\frac{\Delta(1+\eta\beta)^{\tau-\Delta}-2[(1+\eta\beta)^{\tau}-1](\tau-\Delta)}{(1+\eta\beta)^{\tau}-(1+\eta\beta)^{\tau-\Delta}-\eta\beta\Delta}

then ψ​(α,∞)𝜓𝛼\psi(\alpha,\infty) is a decreasing function of α𝛼\alpha, minimized at α=1𝛼1\alpha=1. This result demonstrates that as data dissimilarity δ𝛿\delta among various edge device larger than a certain threshold, the global parameters across the overall federated system dominates the learning performance such that α=1𝛼1\alpha=1 becomes the optimum. The large dissimilarity reduces the importance of any particular local model since it becomes harder for any of them to truly reflect the characteristics of the overall data. Only by gathering different local models across the network can the learning system form a representative whole for all data participated in the training. Otherwise, the optimal α∈(0,1]𝛼01\alpha\in(0,1] is

α=2​η​L​τ​[(1+η​β)τ−1][η​Δ​L​[2​(1+η​β)τ+(1+η​β)τ−Δ−2]−δβ​(1+η​β)τ−Δ​[(1+η​β)Δ−1]+η​δ​Δ].𝛼2𝜂𝐿𝜏delimited-[]superscript1𝜂𝛽𝜏1delimited-[]𝜂Δ𝐿delimited-[]2superscript1𝜂𝛽𝜏superscript1𝜂𝛽𝜏Δ2𝛿𝛽superscript1𝜂𝛽𝜏Δdelimited-[]superscript1𝜂𝛽Δ1𝜂𝛿Δ\displaystyle\alpha=\sqrt{\frac{2\eta L\tau[(1+\eta\beta)^{\tau}-1]}{\left[\begin{array}[]{c}\eta\Delta L[2(1+\eta\beta)^{\tau}+(1+\eta\beta)^{\tau-\Delta}-2]\\ -\frac{\delta}{\beta}(1+\eta\beta)^{\tau-\Delta}[(1+\eta\beta)^{\Delta}-1]+\eta\delta\Delta\end{array}\right]}}.

In Theorem 1, notice that F​(𝐰K)𝐹superscript𝐰𝐾F(\mathbf{w}^{K}) does not converge to the optimum as T𝑇T increases to infinity. This is due to the fact that the model parameters obtained by FedDelAvg with any fixed learning rate η𝜂\eta will converge to a sub-optimal point. Reference [11] proved that the decay of learning rate in each training iteration is necessary for FedAvg to converge even when assuming the loss function to be strongly convex and smooth. We leave the algorithm design and convergence analysis for this more general case for future work.

III-B Proof of Theorem 1

In order to prove Theorem 1, we introduce several properties of FedDelAvg through supporting lemmas and propositions. The detailed proofs are provided in Appendix A.

Lemma 3.

Under Assumption 1, with η<2β𝜂2𝛽\eta<\frac{2}{\beta}, we have

‖𝐰i​(k​τ−Δ)−𝐰​(k​τ−Δ)‖≤ϵ(k)normsubscript𝐰𝑖𝑘𝜏Δ𝐰𝑘𝜏Δsuperscriptitalic-ϵ𝑘\displaystyle\|\mathbf{w}_{i}(k\tau-\Delta)-\mathbf{w}(k\tau-\Delta)\|\leq\epsilon^{(k)} (23)

for all k∈1,2,…,K𝑘12…𝐾k\in{1,2,...,K}, where

ϵ(k)=[1−(1−α)k]​2​η​L​(τ/α−Δ).superscriptitalic-ϵ𝑘delimited-[]1superscript1𝛼𝑘2𝜂𝐿𝜏𝛼Δ\displaystyle\epsilon^{(k)}=[1-(1-\alpha)^{k}]2\eta L(\tau/\alpha-\Delta). (24)

Lemma 3 bounds the error between the local model 𝐰i​(t)subscript𝐰𝑖𝑡\mathbf{w}_{i}(t) and the global 𝐰​(t)𝐰𝑡\mathbf{w}(t) by ϵ(k)superscriptitalic-ϵ𝑘\epsilon^{(k)} at time t=k​τ−Δ𝑡𝑘𝜏Δt=k\tau-\Delta for all k𝑘k. It can be observed that the difference between 𝐰i​(t)subscript𝐰𝑖𝑡\mathbf{w}_{i}(t) and 𝐰​(t)𝐰𝑡\mathbf{w}(t), depending on α𝛼\alpha, increases as the training process continues. However, the rate of increase in this difference continues to decrease until ϵ(k)superscriptitalic-ϵ𝑘\epsilon^{(k)} converges.

This proof is consistent with our intuition that all of local models should all converge to a similar point as training continues. Notice that if there is no global aggregation throughout the training process (α=0𝛼0\alpha=0), the bound diverges. Since each device only has access to its own data, this agrees with our intuition that the local model parameters would diverge due to data dissimilarity between the devices as the training continues.

Lemma 4.

Under Assumption 1, with η<2β𝜂2𝛽\eta<\frac{2}{\beta}, we have, for t∈𝒯k∖{k​τ}𝑡subscript𝒯𝑘𝑘𝜏t\in\mathcal{T}_{k}\setminus\{k\tau\},

‖𝐰i​(t)−𝒄k​(t)‖≤(1+η​β)​‖𝐰i​(t−1)−𝒄k​(t−1)‖+η​δi.normsubscript𝐰𝑖𝑡subscript𝒄𝑘𝑡1𝜂𝛽normsubscript𝐰𝑖𝑡1subscript𝒄𝑘𝑡1𝜂subscript𝛿𝑖\displaystyle\|\mathbf{w}_{i}(t)-\bm{c}_{k}(t)\|\leq(1+\eta\beta)\|\mathbf{w}_{i}(t-1)-\bm{c}_{k}(t-1)\|+\eta\delta_{i}.

Since 𝒄k​(t)subscript𝒄𝑘𝑡\bm{c}_{k}(t) is equivalent to 𝐰​(t)𝐰𝑡\mathbf{w}(t) at t=k​τ−Δ𝑡𝑘𝜏Δt=k\tau-\Delta by definition, Lemma 4 quantifies the divergence between the local model parameter 𝐰i​(t)subscript𝐰𝑖𝑡\mathbf{w}_{i}(t) and the auxiliary centralized GD model parameter 𝒄k​(t)subscript𝒄𝑘𝑡\bm{c}_{k}(t) at time t𝑡t in terms of ϵ(k)superscriptitalic-ϵ𝑘\epsilon^{(k)} from Lemma 3. It can be observed that the difference between local model 𝐰i​((k+1)​τ−Δ)subscript𝐰𝑖𝑘1𝜏Δ\mathbf{w}_{i}((k+1)\tau-\Delta) and global model 𝐰​((k+1)​τ−Δ)𝐰𝑘1𝜏Δ\mathbf{w}((k+1)\tau-\Delta) induces an exponential growth on the bound, dominated by the effects of ϵ(k)superscriptitalic-ϵ𝑘\epsilon^{(k)} and the dissimilarity of data distributions among different edge devices δisubscript𝛿𝑖\delta_{i} with respect to t𝑡t. This exponentially growing term disappears when the communication delay is not considered due to the fact that 𝐰i​(t)=𝒄k​(t)subscript𝐰𝑖𝑡subscript𝒄𝑘𝑡\mathbf{w}_{i}(t)=\bm{c}_{k}(t) at time t=k​τ𝑡𝑘𝜏t=k\tau for all k𝑘k. In this case, the bound becomes

‖𝐰i​(t)−𝒄k​(t)‖≤normsubscript𝐰𝑖𝑡subscript𝒄𝑘𝑡absent\displaystyle\|\mathbf{w}_{i}(t)-\bm{c}_{k}(t)\|\leq δiβ​((β​η+1)t−k​τ−1),subscript𝛿𝑖𝛽superscript𝛽𝜂1𝑡𝑘𝜏1\displaystyle\frac{\delta_{i}}{\beta}\Big{(}(\beta\eta+1)^{t-k\tau}-1\Big{)}, (25)

which is the same as derived in [13, Lemma 3].

Lemma 5.

Under Assumption 1 with η<2β𝜂2𝛽\eta<\frac{2}{\beta}, we have

‖𝐰​(k​τ)−𝒄k​(k​τ)‖≤norm𝐰𝑘𝜏subscript𝒄𝑘𝑘𝜏absent\displaystyle\|\mathbf{w}(k\tau)-\bm{c}_{k}(k\tau)\|\leq
α​Δ​L​η+(1−α)​[((1+η​β)Δ−1)​ϵ(k)+h​(Δ)].𝛼Δ𝐿𝜂1𝛼delimited-[]superscript1𝜂𝛽Δ1superscriptitalic-ϵ𝑘ℎΔ\displaystyle\alpha\Delta L\eta+(1-\alpha)\Big{[}((1+\eta\beta)^{\Delta}-1)\epsilon^{(k)}+h(\Delta)\Big{]}. (26)

Lemma 5 shows the effect of global aggregation on the gap between 𝐰​(k​τ)𝐰𝑘𝜏\mathbf{w}(k\tau) and 𝒄k​(k​τ)subscript𝒄𝑘𝑘𝜏\bm{c}_{k}(k\tau). The gap is dominated by two factors Δ​L​ηΔ𝐿𝜂\Delta L\eta and ((1+η​β)Δ−1)​ϵ(k)+h​(Δ)superscript1𝜂𝛽Δ1superscriptitalic-ϵ𝑘ℎΔ((1+\eta\beta)^{\Delta}-1)\epsilon^{(k)}+h(\Delta), which characterize the influence from the global model and the local model, respectively. Notice that when communication delay is not considered (i.e., α=1𝛼1\alpha=1,Δ=0Δ0\Delta=0), ‖𝐰​(k​τ)−𝒄k​(k​τ)‖≤0norm𝐰𝑘𝜏subscript𝒄𝑘𝑘𝜏0\|\mathbf{w}(k\tau)-\bm{c}_{k}(k\tau)\|\leq 0 at t=k​τ𝑡𝑘𝜏t=k\tau. This can be expected since global aggregation is performed at time t=k​τ𝑡𝑘𝜏t=k\tau for all k𝑘k such that we have 𝐰​(k​τ−Δ)𝐰𝑘𝜏Δ\mathbf{w}(k\tau-\Delta) = 𝒄k​(k​τ−Δ)subscript𝒄𝑘𝑘𝜏Δ\bm{c}_{k}(k\tau-\Delta) by definition.

Proposition 1.

Under Assumption 1 and η<2/β𝜂2𝛽\eta<2/\beta, we have

‖𝐰​((k+1)​τ−Δ)−𝒄k​((k+1)​τ−Δ)‖norm𝐰𝑘1𝜏Δsubscript𝒄𝑘𝑘1𝜏Δ\displaystyle\|\mathbf{w}((k+1)\tau-\Delta)-\bm{c}_{k}((k+1)\tau-\Delta)\| (27)
≤ψ​(α,k)≜(1−α)​ϵ(k)​{[1+η​β]τ−1}absent𝜓𝛼𝑘≜1𝛼superscriptitalic-ϵ𝑘superscriptdelimited-[]1𝜂𝛽𝜏1\displaystyle\leq\psi(\alpha,k)\triangleq(1-\alpha)\epsilon^{(k)}\{[1+\eta\beta]^{\tau}-1\}
+(1−α)​h​(τ)+α​h​(τ−Δ)+α​η​Δ​L​[1+η​β]τ−Δ,1𝛼ℎ𝜏𝛼ℎ𝜏Δ𝛼𝜂Δ𝐿superscriptdelimited-[]1𝜂𝛽𝜏Δ\displaystyle+(1-\alpha)h(\tau)+\alpha h(\tau-\Delta)+\alpha\eta\Delta L[1+\eta\beta]^{\tau-\Delta},

such that

∥F(𝐰((k+1)τ\displaystyle\|F(\mathbf{w}((k+1)\tau −Δ))−F(𝒄k((k+1)τ−Δ))∥≤Lψ(α,k).\displaystyle-\Delta))-F(\bm{c}_{k}((k+1)\tau-\Delta))\|\leq L\psi(\alpha,k).

Proposition 1 quantifies the upper bound on the divergence between the global model parameter 𝐰​(t)𝐰𝑡\mathbf{w}(t) and the auxiliary parameter 𝒄k​(t)subscript𝒄𝑘𝑡\bm{c}_{k}(t) at t=(k+1)​τ−Δ𝑡𝑘1𝜏Δt=(k+1)\tau-\Delta.

When the communication delay is negligible (Δ=0Δ0\Delta=0) and α=1𝛼1\alpha=1, we see that ψ​(α,k)𝜓𝛼𝑘\psi(\alpha,k) converges to

‖𝐰​((k+1)​τ)−𝒄k​((k+1)​τ)‖≤δβ​((β​η+1)τ−1)−η​δ​τ,norm𝐰𝑘1𝜏subscript𝒄𝑘𝑘1𝜏𝛿𝛽superscript𝛽𝜂1𝜏1𝜂𝛿𝜏\displaystyle\|\mathbf{w}((k+1)\tau)-\bm{c}_{k}((k+1)\tau)\|\leq\frac{\delta}{\beta}\Big{(}(\beta\eta+1)^{\tau}-1\Big{)}-\eta\delta\tau,

which is consistent with the result derived in [13, Theorem 1], showing that FedDelAvg and FedAvg are equivalent when α=1𝛼1\alpha=1 with no delay.

When the communication delay is non-negligible (Δ>0)Δ0(\Delta>0) and α≤1𝛼1\alpha\leq 1, ψ​(α,k)𝜓𝛼𝑘\psi(\alpha,k) shifts from (i) ϵ(k)​{[1+η​β]τ−1}+h​(τ)superscriptitalic-ϵ𝑘superscriptdelimited-[]1𝜂𝛽𝜏1ℎ𝜏\epsilon^{(k)}\{[1+\eta\beta]^{\tau}-1\}+h(\tau) to (ii) η​Δ​L​[1+η​β]τ−Δ+h​(τ−Δ)𝜂Δ𝐿superscriptdelimited-[]1𝜂𝛽𝜏Δℎ𝜏Δ\eta\Delta L[1+\eta\beta]^{\tau-\Delta}+h(\tau-\Delta) as α𝛼\alpha goes from 00 to 111. Since factors (i) and (ii) are dominated by α𝛼\alpha and 1−α1𝛼1-\alpha respectively, they correspond to the degree of influence the global and local models have on the bound respectively. We analyze the characteristics of the bound under two cases: α=1𝛼1\alpha=1 and α<1𝛼1\alpha<1. When α=1𝛼1\alpha=1, the bound remains fixed at t=(k+1)​τ−Δ𝑡𝑘1𝜏Δt=(k+1)\tau-\Delta for all k𝑘k since the local models are synchronized to the same value after global aggregation. When α<1𝛼1\alpha<1, the bound does not remain the same for all time t=(k+1)​τ−Δ𝑡𝑘1𝜏Δt=(k+1)\tau-\Delta as k𝑘k increases since the local models are synchronized to different values after global aggregation. From Proposition 1, it can be observed that the alteration of the bound is characterized by ϵ(k)superscriptitalic-ϵ𝑘\epsilon^{(k)}. Therefore, similar to Lemma 3, the bound increases in the beginning while the rate of increase continues to decrease as the training process continues until it converges.

In [15], these results are combined together to prove Theorem 1 as follows. We first bound the error between the local and global model by ϵ(k)superscriptitalic-ϵ𝑘\epsilon^{(k)} at every initialization point of 𝒄k​(t)subscript𝒄𝑘𝑡\bm{c}_{k}(t) using Lemma 3. Since 𝒄k​(t)=𝐰​(t)subscript𝒄𝑘𝑡𝐰𝑡\bm{c}_{k}(t)=\mathbf{w}(t) at the initialization points t=k​τ−Δ𝑡𝑘𝜏Δt=k\tau-\Delta, we can then bound the divergence between the local model 𝐰i​(t)subscript𝐰𝑖𝑡\mathbf{w}_{i}(t) and 𝒄k​(t)subscript𝒄𝑘𝑡\bm{c}_{k}(t) for t∈{k​τ−Δ,…,k​τ−1}𝑡𝑘𝜏Δ…𝑘𝜏1t\in\{k\tau-\Delta,...,k\tau-1\} by combining ϵ(k)superscriptitalic-ϵ𝑘\epsilon^{(k)} with the recursive relationship in Lemma 4. Considering the synchronization phase of FedDelAvg, we further bound the divergence between the global model 𝐰​(t)𝐰𝑡\mathbf{w}(t) and 𝒄k​(t)subscript𝒄𝑘𝑡\bm{c}_{k}(t) at t=k​τ𝑡𝑘𝜏t=k\tau using results in Lemma 4. Finally, applying Lemma 5, we quantify the upper bound on the divergence between the global model 𝐰​(t)𝐰𝑡\mathbf{w}(t) and 𝒄k​(t)subscript𝒄𝑘𝑡\bm{c}_{k}(t) at t=(k+1)​τ−Δ𝑡𝑘1𝜏Δt=(k+1)\tau-\Delta in Proposition 1. Combining the upper bound obtained in Proposition 1 with the convergence property of 𝒄k​(t)subscript𝒄𝑘𝑡\bm{c}_{k}(t) then completes the proof of Theorem 1.

IV Experimental Evaluation

To verify our theoretical results, we conduct numerical experiments to examine the effect of communication delay on the convergence of federated learning. The simulation is carried out using the TensorFlow Federated (TFF) framework [15]. Considering the fact that cloud would only have access to the global model at t=k​τ−Δ𝑡𝑘𝜏Δt=k\tau-\Delta for all k𝑘k when the delay between edge and cloud are carefully considered, we evaluate the averaged model ΔΔ\Delta iterations before each global synchronization on the corresponding global loss function.

We consider a federated learning system with N=10𝑁10N=10 edge devices. The number of local update steps between two global aggregations is set to τ=10𝜏10\tau=10, communication delay is set to Δ=9Δ9\Delta=9, and the total number of global aggregation steps is set to K=100𝐾100K=100.
Dataset. The MNIST dataset [16] containing 70K images (60K for training and 10K for testing) of hand-written digits is considered in the simulation. We distribute the dataset among the edge devices in a manner such that each obtains a subset corresponding to a specific writer. Since each writer has an unique writing style, the data exhibits dissimilarity (δ>0𝛿0\delta>0) among devices (data dissimilarity is referred to as “non-iid” in the literature, see [4]).
ML model. We consider a generic multinominal logistic regression machine learning model to predict the label of each image out of s=10𝑠10s=10 possible classes. The cross-entropy loss fi​(𝐱,y;𝐰)=−∑j=1s{y=j}​log⁡e𝐰jT​𝐱​(∑l=1se𝐰lT​𝐱)−1subscript𝑓𝑖𝐱𝑦𝐰superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑠𝑦𝑗superscript𝑒superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑗𝑇𝐱superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑙1𝑠superscript𝑒superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑙𝑇𝐱1f_{i}(\mathbf{x},y;\mathbf{w})=-\sum\limits_{j=1}^{s}\{y=j\}\log e^{\mathbf{w}_{j}^{T}\mathbf{x}}\Big{(}\sum\limits_{l=1}^{s}e^{\mathbf{w}_{l}^{T}\mathbf{x}}\Big{)}^{-1}, which satisfies Assumptions 1 and 2, is applied as the loss function at each edge device. During the local updating process, each edge device performs gradient descent with full batch size and a fixed learning rate η=0.02𝜂0.02\eta=0.02.

We study the effects of the two key parameters – the weighting α𝛼\alpha which we control, and the communication delay ΔΔ\Delta which is an artifact of the system – on Federated Delayed Average Learning. The convergence of the testing accuracy, defined as the fraction of classes predicted correctly relative to the total number of predictions, is demonstrated with respect to different values of α𝛼\alpha and ΔΔ\Delta.

Fig.2 depicts the improvement in testing accuracy by aggregation for different values of α𝛼\alpha. The convergence speed varies with respect to different values of α𝛼\alpha. Compared with FedAvg (α=1𝛼1\alpha=1), FedDelAvg gains the best improvement with α=0.2𝛼0.2\alpha=0.2: the model reaches an accuracy of roughly 80%percent8080\% in 78%percent7878\% fewer training iterations.

Observing the best selection of α𝛼\alpha in Fig.2, we set α=0.2𝛼0.2\alpha=0.2 and compare FedDelAvg with FedAvg when delay is either negligible or non-negligible (Δ=0Δ0\Delta=0 and Δ=9Δ9\Delta=9) in terms of accuracy. As shown in Fig. LABEL:fig4, when communication delay between edge and cloud is negligible (Δ=0Δ0\Delta=0), FedAvg obtains the best performance in terms of convergence rate, verifying our conclusion in Theorem 1 that α=1𝛼1\alpha=1 is the optimum when Δ=0Δ0\Delta=0. To further demonstrate the delay robustness of FedDelAvg, we set the performance of FedAvg with no delay (Δ=0Δ0\Delta=0) as benchmark and compare it with FedDelAvg under delay (Δ=9Δ9\Delta=9) when α𝛼\alpha is optimized. We observe that, even when the delay is non-negligible, FedDelAvg achieves an accuracy of 80% while only requiring 10% extra training iterations compared with the benchmark. After 100 aggregations, FedDelAvg achieves an accuracy within 3% of the benchmark, whereas FedAvg has a severely degraded performance, thus demonstrating the delay-robustness of the proposed algorithm.

V Conclusion

This paper proposed FedDelAvg, a generalized federated averaging algorithm that incorporates communication delay in edge networks. Analysis of the convergence bound of FedDelAvg was conducted with respect to dissimilarities of local data at each device. The experimental results demonstrated the impact of delays on federated learning and the delay-robustness of FedDelAvg. Overall, we found that the global model converges significantly faster when the synchronization weighting is optimized for the delay compared with existing FL algorithms where local models are not considered during synchronization.

Appendix A

A-A Proof of Lemma 1

Lemma 1.

Under any F𝐹F satisfying Assumption 1, we have

‖[𝐰1−η​∇F​(𝐰1)]−[𝐰2−η​∇F​(𝐰2)]‖≤1+β2​η2​‖𝐰1−𝐰2‖normdelimited-[]subscript𝐰1𝜂∇𝐹subscript𝐰1delimited-[]subscript𝐰2𝜂∇𝐹subscript𝐰21superscript𝛽2superscript𝜂2normsubscript𝐰1subscript𝐰2\|[\mathbf{w}_{1}-\eta\nabla F(\mathbf{w}_{1})]-[\mathbf{w}_{2}-\eta\nabla F(\mathbf{w}_{2})]\|\leq\sqrt{1+\beta^{2}\eta^{2}}\|\mathbf{w}_{1}-\mathbf{w}_{2}\|
≤(1+β​η)​‖𝐰1−𝐰2‖.absent1𝛽𝜂normsubscript𝐰1subscript𝐰2\leq(1+\beta\eta)\|\mathbf{w}_{1}-\mathbf{w}_{2}\|.
Proof.

Note that, from the convexity of F𝐹F, it follows that

F​(𝐰2)≥F​(𝐰1)+(𝐰2−𝐰1)T​∇F​(𝐰1)𝐹subscript𝐰2𝐹subscript𝐰1superscriptsubscript𝐰2subscript𝐰1𝑇∇𝐹subscript𝐰1\displaystyle F(\mathbf{w}_{2})\geq F(\mathbf{w}_{1})+(\mathbf{w}_{2}-\mathbf{w}_{1})^{T}\nabla F(\mathbf{w}_{1}) (28)

Summing both inequalities, we obtain

(𝐰2−𝐰1)T(∇F(𝐰2)−∇F(𝐰1)≥0.(\mathbf{w}_{2}-\mathbf{w}_{1})^{T}(\nabla F(\mathbf{w}_{2})-\nabla F(\mathbf{w}_{1})\geq 0.

Then,

‖[𝐰1−η​∇F​(𝐰1)]−[𝐰2−η​∇F​(𝐰2)]‖2superscriptnormdelimited-[]subscript𝐰1𝜂∇𝐹subscript𝐰1delimited-[]subscript𝐰2𝜂∇𝐹subscript𝐰22\displaystyle\|[\mathbf{w}_{1}-\eta\nabla F(\mathbf{w}_{1})]-[\mathbf{w}_{2}-\eta\nabla F(\mathbf{w}_{2})]\|^{2} (30)
=‖𝐰1−𝐰2‖2+η2​‖∇F​(𝐰1)−∇F​(𝐰2)‖2absentsuperscriptnormsubscript𝐰1subscript𝐰22superscript𝜂2superscriptnorm∇𝐹subscript𝐰1∇𝐹subscript𝐰22\displaystyle=\|\mathbf{w}_{1}-\mathbf{w}_{2}\|^{2}+\eta^{2}\|\nabla F(\mathbf{w}_{1})-\nabla F(\mathbf{w}_{2})\|^{2} (31)
−2​[𝐰2−𝐰1]​[∇F​(𝐰2)−η​∇F​(𝐰1)]2delimited-[]subscript𝐰2subscript𝐰1delimited-[]∇𝐹subscript𝐰2𝜂∇𝐹subscript𝐰1\displaystyle-2[\mathbf{w}_{2}-\mathbf{w}_{1}][\nabla F(\mathbf{w}_{2})-\eta\nabla F(\mathbf{w}_{1})] (32)
≤(1+β2​η2)​‖𝐰1−𝐰2‖2,absent1superscript𝛽2superscript𝜂2superscriptnormsubscript𝐰1subscript𝐰22\displaystyle\leq(1+\beta^{2}\eta^{2})\|\mathbf{w}_{1}-\mathbf{w}_{2}\|^{2}, (33)

A-D Proof of Lemma 4

Lemma 4.

Under Assumption 1, with learning rate η<2β𝜂2𝛽\eta<\frac{2}{\beta}, we have, for t∈(k​τ−Δ,(k+1)​τ−Δ),t≠k​τformulae-sequence𝑡𝑘𝜏Δ𝑘1𝜏Δ𝑡𝑘𝜏t\in(k\tau-\Delta,(k+1)\tau-\Delta),t\neq k\tau,

‖𝐰i​(t)−𝒄k​(t)‖≤(1+η​β)​‖𝐰i​(t−1)−𝒄k​(t−1)‖+η​δi.normsubscript𝐰𝑖𝑡subscript𝒄𝑘𝑡1𝜂𝛽normsubscript𝐰𝑖𝑡1subscript𝒄𝑘𝑡1𝜂subscript𝛿𝑖\displaystyle\|\mathbf{w}_{i}(t)-\bm{c}_{k}(t)\|\leq(1+\eta\beta)\|\mathbf{w}_{i}(t-1)-\bm{c}_{k}(t-1)\|+\eta\delta_{i}.
Proof.

Let t∈(k​τ−Δ,(k+1)​τ−Δ),t≠k​τformulae-sequence𝑡𝑘𝜏Δ𝑘1𝜏Δ𝑡𝑘𝜏t\in(k\tau-\Delta,(k+1)\tau-\Delta),t\neq k\tau. We have

𝐰i​(t)−𝒄k​(t)=𝐰i​(t−1)−𝒄k​(t−1)subscript𝐰𝑖𝑡subscript𝒄𝑘𝑡subscript𝐰𝑖𝑡1subscript𝒄𝑘𝑡1\displaystyle\mathbf{w}_{i}(t)-\bm{c}_{k}(t)=\mathbf{w}_{i}(t-1)-\bm{c}_{k}(t-1)

+η​[∇F​(𝒄k​(t−1))−∇Fi​(𝒄k​(t−1))].𝜂delimited-[]∇𝐹subscript𝒄𝑘𝑡1∇subscript𝐹𝑖subscript𝒄𝑘𝑡1\displaystyle+\eta[\nabla F(\bm{c}_{k}(t-1))-\nabla F_{i}(\bm{c}_{k}(t-1))].

Taking the norm and using the triangular inequality, we then obtain

‖𝐰i​(t)−𝒄k​(t)‖≤‖𝐰i​(t−1)−𝒄k​(t−1)‖normsubscript𝐰𝑖𝑡subscript𝒄𝑘𝑡normsubscript𝐰𝑖𝑡1subscript𝒄𝑘𝑡1\displaystyle\|\mathbf{w}_{i}(t)-\bm{c}_{k}(t)\|\leq\|\mathbf{w}_{i}(t-1)-\bm{c}_{k}(t-1)\|
+η​‖∇Fi​(𝒄k​(t−1))−∇Fi​(𝐰i​(t−1))‖𝜂norm∇subscript𝐹𝑖subscript𝒄𝑘𝑡1∇subscript𝐹𝑖subscript𝐰𝑖𝑡1\displaystyle+\eta\|\nabla F_{i}(\bm{c}_{k}(t-1))-\nabla F_{i}(\mathbf{w}_{i}(t-1))\|
+η​‖∇F​(𝒄k​(t−1))−∇Fi​(𝒄k​(t−1))‖.𝜂norm∇𝐹subscript𝒄𝑘𝑡1∇subscript𝐹𝑖subscript𝒄𝑘𝑡1\displaystyle+\eta\|\nabla F(\bm{c}_{k}(t-1))-\nabla F_{i}(\bm{c}_{k}(t-1))\|.

The result of the lemma is then found by using the β𝛽\beta-smoothness of Fi​(⋅)subscript𝐹𝑖⋅F_{i}(\cdot) and Assumption 2. ∎

A-E Proof of Lemma 5

Lemma 5.

Under Assumption 1 with learning rate η<2/β𝜂2𝛽\eta<2/\beta, we have

‖𝐰​(k​τ)−𝒄k​(k​τ)‖≤η​Δ​[α​L+(1−α)​β​ϵ(k)]norm𝐰𝑘𝜏subscript𝒄𝑘𝑘𝜏𝜂Δdelimited-[]𝛼𝐿1𝛼𝛽superscriptitalic-ϵ𝑘\displaystyle\|\mathbf{w}(k\tau)-\bm{c}_{k}(k\tau)\|\leq\eta\Delta\left[\alpha L+(1-\alpha)\beta\epsilon^{(k)}\right] (47)
+(1−α)​(βδ​ϵ(k)+1)​h​(Δ).1𝛼𝛽𝛿superscriptitalic-ϵ𝑘1ℎΔ\displaystyle+(1-\alpha)\left(\frac{\beta}{\delta}\epsilon^{(k)}+1\right)h(\Delta). (48)
=α​Δ​L​η+(1−α)​[((1+η​β)Δ−1)​ϵ(k)+h​(Δ)].absent𝛼Δ𝐿𝜂1𝛼delimited-[]superscript1𝜂𝛽Δ1superscriptitalic-ϵ𝑘ℎΔ\displaystyle=\alpha\Delta L\eta+(1-\alpha)\Big{[}((1+\eta\beta)^{\Delta}-1)\epsilon^{(k)}+h(\Delta)\Big{]}. (49)
Proof.

Note that, using (A-C)

𝐰​(k​τ)=∑iρi​𝐰i​(k​τ)𝐰𝑘𝜏subscript𝑖subscript𝜌𝑖subscript𝐰𝑖𝑘𝜏\displaystyle\mathbf{w}(k\tau)=\sum_{i}\rho_{i}\mathbf{w}_{i}(k\tau) (50)
=𝐰​(k​τ−Δ)−(1−α)​η​∑r=1Δ∑iρi​∇Fi​(𝐰i​(k​τ−r)).absent𝐰𝑘𝜏Δ1𝛼𝜂superscriptsubscript𝑟1Δsubscript𝑖subscript𝜌𝑖∇subscript𝐹𝑖subscript𝐰𝑖𝑘𝜏𝑟\displaystyle=\mathbf{w}(k\tau-\Delta)-(1-\alpha)\eta\sum\limits_{r=1}^{\Delta}\sum_{i}\rho_{i}\nabla F_{i}(\mathbf{w}_{i}(k\tau-r)). (51)

𝒄k​(k​τ)subscript𝒄𝑘𝑘𝜏\displaystyle\bm{c}_{k}(k\tau) =𝒄k​(k​τ−Δ)−η​∑r=1Δ∑iρi​∇Fi​(𝒄k​(k​τ−r)).absentsubscript𝒄𝑘𝑘𝜏Δ𝜂superscriptsubscript𝑟1Δsubscript𝑖subscript𝜌𝑖∇subscript𝐹𝑖subscript𝒄𝑘𝑘𝜏𝑟\displaystyle=\bm{c}_{k}(k\tau-\Delta)-\eta\sum\limits_{r=1}^{\Delta}\sum\limits_{i}\rho_{i}\nabla F_{i}(\bm{c}_{k}(k\tau-r)). (52)

Therefore, we obtain

𝐰​(k​τ)−𝒄k​(k​τ)=η​α​∑r=1Δ∑iρi​∇Fi​(𝒄k​(k​τ−r))𝐰𝑘𝜏subscript𝒄𝑘𝑘𝜏𝜂𝛼superscriptsubscript𝑟1Δsubscript𝑖subscript𝜌𝑖∇subscript𝐹𝑖subscript𝒄𝑘𝑘𝜏𝑟\displaystyle\mathbf{w}(k\tau)-\bm{c}_{k}(k\tau)=\eta\alpha\sum\limits_{r=1}^{\Delta}\sum_{i}\rho_{i}\nabla F_{i}(\bm{c}_{k}(k\tau-r)) (53)
−(1−α)​η​∑r=1Δ∑iρi​[∇Fi​(𝐰i​(k​τ−r))−∇Fi​(𝒄k​(k​τ−r))]1𝛼𝜂superscriptsubscript𝑟1Δsubscript𝑖subscript𝜌𝑖delimited-[]∇subscript𝐹𝑖subscript𝐰𝑖𝑘𝜏𝑟∇subscript𝐹𝑖subscript𝒄𝑘𝑘𝜏𝑟\displaystyle-(1-\alpha)\eta\sum\limits_{r=1}^{\Delta}\sum_{i}\rho_{i}[\nabla F_{i}(\mathbf{w}_{i}(k\tau-r))-\nabla F_{i}(\bm{c}_{k}(k\tau-r))] (54)

‖𝐰​(k​τ)−𝒄k​(k​τ)‖≤η​α​∑r=1Δ∑iρi​‖∇Fi​(𝒄k​(k​τ−r))‖norm𝐰𝑘𝜏subscript𝒄𝑘𝑘𝜏𝜂𝛼superscriptsubscript𝑟1Δsubscript𝑖subscript𝜌𝑖norm∇subscript𝐹𝑖subscript𝒄𝑘𝑘𝜏𝑟\displaystyle\|\mathbf{w}(k\tau)-\bm{c}_{k}(k\tau)\|\leq\eta\alpha\sum\limits_{r=1}^{\Delta}\sum_{i}\rho_{i}\|\nabla F_{i}(\bm{c}_{k}(k\tau-r))\| (55)

A-G Proof of Proposition 2

A-H Proof of Theorem 1

Theorem 1.

If Fi​(⋅)subscript𝐹𝑖⋅F_{i}(\cdot) is convex, L𝐿L-Lipschitz and β𝛽\beta-smooth, when η<2β𝜂2𝛽\eta<\frac{2}{\beta},

F​(𝒘𝑲)−F​(𝒘∗)𝐹superscript𝒘𝑲𝐹superscript𝒘\displaystyle F(\bm{w^{K}})-F(\bm{w^{*}}) (101)
≤12​η​ϕ​T+14​η2​ϕ2​T2+L​Ψ​(α)η​ϕ​T+L​ψ​(α,K).absent12𝜂italic-ϕ𝑇14superscript𝜂2superscriptitalic-ϕ2superscript𝑇2𝐿Ψ𝛼𝜂italic-ϕ𝑇𝐿𝜓𝛼𝐾\displaystyle\leq\frac{1}{2\eta\phi T}+\sqrt{\frac{1}{4\eta^{2}\phi^{2}T^{2}}+\frac{L\Psi(\alpha)}{\eta\phi T}}+L\psi(\alpha,K). (102)

where Ψ​(α)=∑k=1Kψ​(α,k)Ψ𝛼superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾𝜓𝛼𝑘\Psi(\alpha)=\sum\limits_{k=1}^{K}\psi(\alpha,k).

Proof.

To derive (35), consider η≤1β𝜂1𝛽\eta\leq\frac{1}{\beta} and let ξ∗>0superscript𝜉0\xi^{*}>0 be defined such that T​η​ϕ−L​Ψ​(α)ξ∗2>0𝑇𝜂italic-ϕ𝐿Ψ𝛼superscript𝜉absent20T\eta\phi-\frac{L\Psi(\alpha)}{\xi^{*2}}>0 and

ξ∗=1T​η​ϕ−L​Ψ​(α)ξ∗2.superscript𝜉1𝑇𝜂italic-ϕ𝐿Ψ𝛼superscript𝜉absent2\displaystyle\xi^{*}=\frac{1}{T\eta\phi-\frac{L\Psi(\alpha)}{\xi^{*2}}}. (103)

Solving, we obtain

ξ∗=12​η​ϕ​T+14​η2​ϕ2​T2+L​Ψ​(α)η​ϕ​Tsuperscript𝜉12𝜂italic-ϕ𝑇14superscript𝜂2superscriptitalic-ϕ2superscript𝑇2𝐿Ψ𝛼𝜂italic-ϕ𝑇\displaystyle\xi^{*}=\frac{1}{2\eta\phi T}+\sqrt{\frac{1}{4\eta^{2}\phi^{2}T^{2}}+\frac{L\Psi(\alpha)}{\eta\phi T}} (104)

(which indeed satisfies T​η​ϕ−L​Ψ​(α)ξ∗2>0𝑇𝜂italic-ϕ𝐿Ψ𝛼superscript𝜉absent20T\eta\phi-\frac{L\Psi(\alpha)}{\xi^{*2}}>0). Now, let ξ>ξ∗𝜉superscript𝜉\xi>\xi^{*}, and assume that, under such ξ𝜉\xi, the conditions of Proposition 2 are all satisfied. Then, it follows that

F​(𝐰​((K+1)​τ−Δ))−F​(𝒘∗)<1T​η​ϕ−L​Ψ​(α)ξ2≤1T​η​ϕ−L​Ψ​(α)ξ∗2=ξ∗<ξ.𝐹𝐰𝐾1𝜏Δ𝐹superscript𝒘1𝑇𝜂italic-ϕ𝐿Ψ𝛼superscript𝜉21𝑇𝜂italic-ϕ𝐿Ψ𝛼superscript𝜉absent2superscript𝜉𝜉\displaystyle F(\mathbf{w}((K+1)\tau-\Delta))-F(\bm{w^{*}})<\frac{1}{T\eta\phi-\frac{L\Psi(\alpha)}{\xi^{2}}}\leq\frac{1}{T\eta\phi-\frac{L\Psi(\alpha)}{\xi^{*2}}}=\xi^{*}<\xi. (105)

In other words, this shows a contradiction with condition (4) of Proposition 2. Therefore, at least one of the conditions of Proposition cannot be satisfied, for any ξ>ξ∗𝜉superscript𝜉\xi>\xi^{*}. Conditions (1) and (2) are clearly satisfied since η≤1/β𝜂1𝛽\eta\leq 1/\beta and

ξ>ξ∗=1T​η​ϕ−L​Ψ​(α)ξ∗2>0.𝜉superscript𝜉1𝑇𝜂italic-ϕ𝐿Ψ𝛼superscript𝜉absent20\xi>\xi^{*}=\frac{1}{T\eta\phi-\frac{L\Psi(\alpha)}{\xi^{*2}}}>0.

Therefore, either conditions (3) or (4) are violated, implying that

min⁡{F​(𝐰​((K+1)​τ−Δ)),mink⁡F​(𝒄k​((k+1)​τ−Δ))}−F​(𝒘∗)≤ξ∗.𝐹𝐰𝐾1𝜏Δsubscript𝑘𝐹subscript𝒄𝑘𝑘1𝜏Δ𝐹superscript𝒘superscript𝜉\displaystyle\min\{F(\mathbf{w}((K+1)\tau-\Delta)),\min_{k}F(\bm{c}_{k}((k+1)\tau-\Delta))\}-F(\bm{w^{*}})\leq\xi^{*}. (106)

Using Proposition 1, we have that

F​(𝐰​((k+1)​τ−Δ))≤F​(𝒄k​((k+1)​τ−Δ))𝐹𝐰𝑘1𝜏Δ𝐹subscript𝒄𝑘𝑘1𝜏Δ\displaystyle F(\mathbf{w}((k+1)\tau-\Delta))\leq F(\bm{c}_{k}((k+1)\tau-\Delta)) (107)
+|F​(𝐰​((k+1)​τ−Δ))−F​(𝒄k​((k+1)​τ−Δ))|𝐹𝐰𝑘1𝜏Δ𝐹subscript𝒄𝑘𝑘1𝜏Δ\displaystyle+|F(\mathbf{w}((k+1)\tau-\Delta))-F(\bm{c}_{k}((k+1)\tau-\Delta))| (108)
≤F​(𝒄k​((k+1)​τ−Δ))absent𝐹subscript𝒄𝑘𝑘1𝜏Δ\displaystyle\leq F(\bm{c}_{k}((k+1)\tau-\Delta)) (109)

The result of the theorem then directly follows.
